Please help us congratulate Ms. Hannah Wielgosz of West Harrison High School!! She just received her certification as an ACT Certified Educator in ACT Basics and ACT English!

"I am blessed to teach the best English I and English II students! In addition, I serve as the head coach for the cross-country team.
I am thankful that I am a part of the Canes family; the students, staff, and administration are the most incredible people to learn from in my first few years of teaching. I love that with this profession, not only am I helping students grow and learn, but I am also growing and learning each year."

We are so proud of you, Ms. Wielgosz!! #HCSDStrong

Big congratulations to Mr. Cody Eadie of Harrison Central High!! He just earned his certification in ACT Basics, ACT English, and ACT Reading!

Mr. Eadie is an eight-year veteran of Harrison Central High, teaching Accelerated English and AP Capstone. His particular specialty is the ACT, as he tutors many students along the Mississippi Gulf Coast. Mr. Eadie has helped dozens of Harrison Central students reach the "ACT 30+ Club". HCHS students who have scored a perfect 36 on their ACT have credited Mr. Eadie for helping them achieve that goal.

Mr. Eadie is also a five-time recipient of the STAR Teacher award and has received the HCHS yearbook dedication and HCHS Teacher of the Year award during his time at HCHC.

Based on his performance, Mr. Eadie has been recruited to serve as an ACT trainer to other educators in the future.

Great job, Mr. Eadie! We are so proud of your achievements!
#HCSDStrong

Congratulations to Mrs. Kristi Roberts of D'Iberville High School!! She just received her certification in ACT Basics and ACT Reading!

Mrs. Roberts is a graduate of Harrison Central High School. She taught 5th grade at Lyman Elementary, then served as a Positive Behavior Specialist at the Special Services Center. Mrs. Roberts also taught special education, general psychology, dual credit psychology, and U.S. History at Harrison Central High. She currently teaches STEM, U.S. History, and dual credit psychology at DHS, and is serving as the chair of the school's Social Studies Department.

Mrs. Roberts is married to Mr. Kevin Roberts. Their two children, Xander and Raegan, both attend school in HCSD.

"I love my job and dedicate countless hours to leaving a lasting positive impact on the students I have the pleasure of teaching. My passion is watching students grow and learn. Many times, students surpass their own expectations with proper instruction and encouragement," said Mrs. Roberts.

We are so proud of you, Mrs. Roberts!!! #HCSDStrong

It was a picture-perfect day to celebrate the official start of construction on another exciting project in the Harrison County School District!! Be sure to catch this story tonight on WLOX-TV, WXXV 25, and the SunHerald!

This morning, HCSD leaders, representatives from D’Iberville, Harrison County, and other special guests gathered to break ground on the new Creekbend Elementary and Middle School. The K-8 school will help alleviate overcrowding on the east side of the county, and the campus can accommodate future growth in the area. The project is part of a $55 million bond issue that voters overwhelmingly approved in 2018.

The 40-acre property is located on Highway 15, just north of the D'Iberville Sports Complex. Creekbend is scheduled to open in August of 2022.

You can check on the progress of all HCSD bond issue projects on our district website: http://www.harrison.k12.ms.us/bond_issue_updates
#HCSDStrong

HCSD holds a Dropout Prevention Team Meeting every school year, and this year, District leaders believe community involvement is more important than ever. post_text: In Chemistry at D’Iberville High today, students reviewed the scientific method by analyzing parts of an episode of MacGyver. They had to identify the steps of the scientific method and explain why it was that step. Instead of the normal answering questions on a worksheet, the students worked together to create videos on Flipgrid, discussing how different scenes implemented the use of the scientific method. If students did not want to create a video, they were able to write their discussions. The goal of the lesson was to not only review the scientific method, but to help students realize that they can use the scientific method beyond the science classroom.

HCSD nurses are back and they spent their first day going over new health modules and updated Mississippi Health Department guidelines on how to open schools while maintaining a safe and healthy learning environment.

Our nurses will be training all teachers and staff at their schools to recognize students who may appear to be sick, along with encouraging important precautions like hand washing, sanitizing, and social distancing.

Our nurses will also be available should parents have any questions or concerns about student health. Plus, they will work closely with school counselors and social workers to assist students with their physical, emotional, and mental health.

“We are blessed and grateful to have a nurse at every school in the Harrison County School District. A majority of our nurses are veterans, so many of our families have come to know them on a personal level. Our nurses are well trained and ready to implement these extra measures for the health, safety, and well-being of our students and staff,” said Dr. Laretta Marks, HCSD Director of Student Services.
#HCSDStrong

Our top priority is the safety and security of our students and staff. That is why Harrison County School District leaders hold Emergency and Crises Response Training before the start of every school year.

This week, HCSD directors, administrators, and instructional literacy coaches took part in a two-day training session with the Mississippi Department of Safety - Office of Homeland Security. This year, training was done online due to COVID-19. Topics included Human Trafficking, Bombs in Schools, and Social Media During the Pandemic.

Today, the focus was on CRASE (Crisis Response to Active Shooter Events). Five years ago, HCSD became the first school district in Mississippi to hold CRASE training for educators.

“Harrison County School District always stays two steps ahead of training,” said Laura Fosselman, MS Office of Homeland Security Training Coordinator.

Harrison Central High celebrated our seniors today with a car parade, sign distribution, and a Class of 2020 Time Capsule!

Seniors lined up in their vehicles at Crosspoint Church on North Swan Road. With Harrison County Sheriff’s Deputies leading the way, the seniors traveled north on Highway 49, turned onto School Road, then headed toward the HCHS campus.

As the seniors’ names were announced, each student received a special yard sign and a bag of goodies. As the students left the campus, they deposited their Time Capsule memorabilia by the front gate. The Time Capsule will be buried on the HCHS campus at a later date.

Many parents, friends, and community supporters showed up with decorated signs and pompoms to cheer on the seniors. It was a memorable and emotional day for everyone!!
#HCSDStrong

Harrison Central High School Junior Dakota Fayard’s original monologue will be featured by Manhattan Theatre Club (MTC) as part of their High School Student Monologue Challenge. MTC selected original monologues internationally submitted by high school students to be featured on their website and social media. Dakota’s featured monologue may be viewed beginning May 2, 2020 at the following link: https://www.manhattantheatreclub.com/education/student-monologue-challenge.

Students were required to write a one minute monologue utilizing the prompt “There is something I need to say to you.” Chase Yano and Dakota Fayard’s monologues are the only Mississippi high school students featured by MTC Education’s High School Student Monologue Challenge. These two Rebel Players are continuing the tradition of Mississippi being recognized for outstanding literary achievements. Congratulations Dakota!!
